title: Light trading amid Lunar New Year holidays - Top10 World
text:
Home / Politics / Light trading amid Lunar New Year holidays Light trading amid Lunar New Year holidays 1 min ago 
Over in Asia, activity was lower than normal with markets in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea, Malaysia and Vietnam closed. 
Japan’s benchmark Nikkei rallied 1.27 percent as the yen wobbled against the greenback. The currency hit a new 15-month high at 105.69 per dollar, extending gains for a second straight day, 
Utilities were among the biggest gainers, with Kansai Electric Power and Chubu Electric Power both jumping more than 5 percent. 
Used-car dealer Idom soared 1.78 percent on news that it is partnering with Uber in Africa. 
Beer manufacturer Sapporo Holdings slumped 4.38 percent after posting a 16 percent drop in 2017 operating profit. 
In economic news, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s administration reappointed Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda for another five-year term in an indication that the country’s stimulus policy will remain unchanged. 
Australian shares reversed earlier gains to trade flat in negative territory while the Australian dollar hit a new two-week high of $0.7969, extending gains into a second session. 
Healthcare stocks led the gains on the benchmark ASX 200 . Private hospital operator Healthscope jumped 6.74 percent on hopes for a potential sale of its Asian pathology business. Primary tacked on 3.68 percent after re porting strong earnings figures. 
The Reserve Bank of Australia plans to leave interest rates at their current record lows for a while, Governor Philip Lowe said on Friday, adding that he hoped for gradual improvement in the unemployment rate.
